message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The picture shows ventriculomegaly, which is a common finding in congenital cytomegalovirus infections. The mother’s occupation as an animal caretaker also puts her at risk for being infected with CMV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only CMV (Cytomegalovirus) can cause microcephaly, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly. The fact that the mother is an animal caretaker increases the likelihood of exposure to the virus. Varicella can cause skin lesions but not the other symptoms mentioned. Toxoplasmosis can cause chorioretinitis but not jaundice or microcephaly. Syphilis can cause nonimmune hydrops fetalis but not microcephaly alone. The CT and MRI findings are consistent with congenital CMV infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows calcifications in the brain in a pattern typical of CMV infection. Jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly suggest a congenital infection. Animal caretakers are at risk of infection with CMV, which can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy. Varicella infection does not typically cause microcephaly or hepatosplenomegaly. Toxoplasmosis and syphilis can also cause congenital infections, but their characteristic findings are different from those seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The picture shows ventriculomegaly, intracerebral calcifications, and hydrocephalus, which are commonly seen in congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. The mother's occupation as an animal caretaker also increases the risk of contracting CMV. Varicella and toxoplasmosis can cause similar symptoms, but the imaging findings are not specific enough to make that diagnosis. Syphilis can cause microcephaly, but not the other imaging findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The microcephaly, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and the head CT/MRI findings are all consistent with congenital CMV infection. Other options are associated with different symptoms and/or head imaging findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only CMV (cytomegalovirus) can cause microcephaly and jaundice in newborns, especially when the mother is exposed to infected bodily fluids through her work with animals. The CT and MRI findings of ventriculomegaly and calcifications in the brain also support the diagnosis of CMV infection. Varicella can cause skin lesions in newborns, Toxoplasmosis can cause hydrocephalus and intracranial calcifications, and Syphilis can cause bone abnormalities but none of these specifically cause microcephaly and jaundice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Microcephaly and jaundice are symptoms of congenital cytomegalovirus infection, and the CT and MRI findings are consistent with this diagnosis. None of the other options have hepatosplenomegaly as a common symptom.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The microcephaly and jaundice along with the CT and MRI findings suggest that the most likely cause is CMV (Cytomegalovirus), which is a common viral infection that can cause birth defects when contracted during pregnancy. Hepatosplenomegaly is also commonly seen in CMV infections. The other options may cause congenital infections as well, but are less likely to present with these specific symptoms and imaging findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including jaundice and microcephaly, and the imaging findings suggest CMV infection during pregnancy. Varicella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital varicella syndrome, but it presents differently than the symptoms seen in this patient. Toxoplasmosis can cause hydrocephalus and calcifications in the brain, but not microcephaly. Syphilis can also cause hydrocephalus and calcifications, but not hepatosplenomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The picture shows calcifications in the periventricular and subcortical areas, which are typical findings seen in congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. The mother’s occupation as an animal caretaker puts her at higher risk for CMV. Varicella and toxoplasmosis would have presented with different symptoms, such as skin lesions or retinochoroiditis, respectively. Syphilis can also cause calcifications but typically involves the long bones and teeth.
